reviews.review_msg: He's awful. He seems pretty knowledgeable of his subject but the way he teaches isn't so easy to understand and it is really hard for 1st year students(especially those who are not major in English) to get what he teaches. I wouldn't recommend him.

Clint Burnham is a washed up writer who resents the world and puts all that resentment on his students. He gives awful advice on writing and often bashes one's work. He would teach what not to do and never tell us why or build us up to become writers. I felt like I became a worse writer in his class and sucked the inspiration out of me. Avoid him.

Burnham is obviously an intelligent person, but he has no interest in hearing others opinions/feedback or teaching in accessible ways. He refused to make his criteria clearer when I asked. He weirdly triggered by random words (like curate?). He will doc you marks if he disagrees with you. 

In private he is open to meeting but very condescending.

Clint's expectations for what he is looking for in assignments are very unclear. He will give you a confusing prompt, give you a bad mark, and THEN tell you what he was looking for in feedback. Information that would have helped in the first place. His feedback can also be rude at times and very unhelpful.

This guy LOVES to pontificate woke and often too-niche opinions in student lectures with students who likely have no idea what he is talking about. He is the kind of prof that will dock marks if he disagrees with you. He makes completely random connections between philosophy, history, psychology, etc, and talks as if everyone knows what he means.
great prof -- super funny & interesting. cares a lot about social causes and often tries to make class relevant to things that are actually happening in the world.

A man for who pedagogy is a four-letter word. Treats his students with contempt, and is only concerned with his own self-aggrandizement. Terminally obsessed with a certain faddish Slovenian philosopher who is now way past his prime.

A very strange guy. He obviously cares a lot about creative writing, just not yours. Dont feel comfortable about sharing your negative life experiences to him in your writing? Expect low grades. Also, hes pretty poor at communicating to female students. His comments are commonly belittling.

I really hated this class. It was incredibly anxiety inducing, stressful, and the synchronous online lectures were the worst thing ever. I could not stand this prof, he was rude and belittling and I learned absolutely nothing except I never want to take a class with him again. Would not recommend unless you want to be depressed and anxious!

I thought Clint was a great person, but not approachable as a professor. His feedback and rubrics were extremely vague and he has an extreme bias in writing. Also, he would rarely respond to student emails. From my perspective, his creative writing class was dry and not helpful at all. Wouldn't take him again.

Lots of work but I found it worth while. My writing really improved and I had a good time in the class. He is a very interesting guy and pretty funny too. He has high expectations so it can be scary after the first few marks come in but he really does care and wants you to improve. I would take another one of his classes without hesitation.

The other reviews here are so harsh :( 99% of the class was female. readings were informative, live discussions & breakout rooms were engaging/fun. I was really challenged & my writing improved a lot. he's also pretty funny, lectures were fun. feedback was hilarious & meme-able, but unclear. pretty sure he bumped everyone's grades up at the end tho

He has high expectations but I genuinely felt my creative writing improved by the end of the semester. He holds all students to high standards and though his grading criteria is not conventionally clear, such is the nature of art and writing. He cares about students and social issues a lot. Be prepared to work hard but he's a super interesting guy

Clint has significantly lessened my desire for creative writing. His feedback is subjective, and the expectations he sets for students are vague. His prescription for what constitutes "good writing" is the magnitude of trauma in the personal experiences you're expected to write about. Thankfully, his class gave me all the trauma I will ever need.

Definitely one of the more challenging profs I've had but I can't complain. He's a tough marker and you have to work for it but that made me strive in the class. I felt driven to get good grades on the papers and he is really just looking for improvement throughout the course. He made me feel very inspired this sem. I really enjoyed him.

Dr. Burnham is the most disrespectful person I have ever had the displeasure of meeting. His expectations for the 200-level are astronomically high and he does not provide any constructive feedback; rather, his feedback is destructive and belittling. He takes special efforts to make women feel small and insignificant. Avoid him at all costs...

I can't even explain the amount of stress and anxiety that I have felt because of this professor. He is a super hard marker, he is flippant and rude (especially to female students) and he does not give any feedback on his papers. His marking is 100% subjective and he makes you feel dumb if you write in a style that he hates.

Burnham doesn't give the explanation necessary for a 1st year course - as a 3rd year student I was explaining assignment requirements to my classmates who felt lost. The classroom environment was not receptive to questions and he shut them down. He seemed particularly dismissive of female students.
Super smart and passionate!

I can see where Clint would be more difficult in a first year course. However, when he teaches fourth year courses, they are insightful and adequately challenging. He is a fair marker, and keeps topics relevant to contemporary issues and topics. He genuinely respects his students. Loved his class.

Here's the thing about Clint- he has bad reviews, obviously. But if you are willing to put in the work, he recognizes your effort and all is peachy-kean. He can come across as arrogant, but part of it is his expectation that those who take his class will be able to fit his standard. So while it's challenging, I think it's worth it.

If you're taking the course to learn more about writing or because you're interested in prose, look elsewhere. I just skipped the last few lectures because all he did was talk about social justice related topics that had little (read: nothing) to do with rhetoric or writing. Very boring. I regret taking the class.
He is rude and pretentious. Do not take a course with this guy because the only way to get an A in this class is to write at his level.

What a ridiculous person. I received a good grade in his class so this is not out of revenge. He is the perfect example of a desperate, aging hipster. Totally full of himself, terrible teaching style. Avoid him if you like avoiding unbearable people, and if you'd like to learn something other than his opinion of himself.

A lot of people reviewing Dr. Burnham give poor reviews because of the difficulty of his subject matter. I agree, it is difficult - but it is also rewarding and is an enticing look at what school will be like when we get past the "literature appreciation" undergraduate phase. I owe to him my interest in theory that I wouldn't have seen otherwise.

Absolutely ridiculously difficult for a first year English course. Extremely unclear parameters for assignments. Applying Lacanian terms in the ways that he wants to the reading material is a virtually impossible task.

Burnham is your not your typical university professor. His use of social media helps students with course access. It was my mistake to take readings for granted; now I'm paying for it (literally). Lacanian terms WILL be the emphasis for all his readings so be sure to get your head around those concepts! But he's an amiable character without a doubt

I had to take English for one of my electives and chose to take 104. If English isn't your strong suit, DON'T TAKE THIS COURSE. It revolves around psychoanalysis and Lacan which to me, doesn't scream English at all...Although he seems extremely knowledgeable in the course content, I feel lost, confused, and no better off than when I started.

It's true. He is all about Lacan, and if he is your TA he is a super hard marker. My writing probably tangibly improved because of him, and I loved all of the readings, but I was really not into the Lacan. Also, he makes you follow him on twitter.Pretty helpful one on one.

You need to go to every lecture to understand the material because you have to apply Lacan to the textbooks. Trust me, it is not an easy parrellel. I don't think he tries to make Eng hard (but the again he wasn't my TA) but instead tries to make it have more depth. His final was very easy as he pretty much told us what was gonna be on it.

Horrible professor. His sole purpose is to make English seem like the hardest class in the University and he will do ANYTHING to achieve that purpose. Besides being an annoying and boring prof he is also an awfull TA. If you wrote your papers on B's and B+'s expect to receive D's when he marks them.
if i can, i want to make him listen to his own lectures...

The lectures are extremely boring, wouldn't recommend on taking his class, doesn't really care about his students. Does pick put good TA thou, but marking is very strict. If i were you, i wouldn't take his class again.

Burnham makes it extremely clear that he thinks nothing of Undergrads and talks over our heads. He presents concepts that no undergrad in second year will have encountered and does not bother to explain them in the slightest. Would clearly rather not be teaching -- or at least only wishes to teach Graduate students. Luckily he does pick great TAs.

extremely knowledgeable; frontloads lectures with information, but facilitates discussions in seminar extremely well. Classes are difficult. Rewarding, but don't expect an easy mark. Excellent for upper division classes if you're interested in more than just a grade.

I am continually offput by this professor. He is arrogant and intentionally obscure; he does not seem to care a wit about students' opinions, thoughts, questions. He's basically what you picture when think of a pretentious university professor.

Unless you enjoy frequent forays into Freudian/Lacanian analysis stay well clear.
 Although he clearly has a huge breadth of knowledge he is not very good at explaining concepts, nor at relating his obsession with Lacan to the coursework (and he will bring Lacan up no matter the course). Also, his way is the right way. Always.
 Engaging lecturer th

He is clearly very talented and very intelligent, but he just can't quite seem to communicate that to us. I don't think he doesn't care, I just think that *teaching* is not necessarily his strong suit.

Often goes off on tangents discussing Freud and psychoanalysis, and doesn't relate lecture material to text/course material clearly. The texts for this course were really interesting, but the lectures hardly drew on the texts.
